With "Joe" England on hand
for coaching, the cross country
team opened its season by taking
•an easy workout over the two-mile
course. The prospects for a good
season are encouraging, for with
only five men to pick for a team
a good selection may be made
from the men of last year's team
and the new men who give promise
of ck‘relopment.
Captain Bartels is giving as

large squad will be well on the

C.C.C. run in Washington around
the middle of November.
The local course at Homewood
has been freshly marked out with
posts and arrows. This will ento train before the main body of
men, to cover the course accurately.

own in the dashes and field events.
Until track at Homewood can
gain the place it holds among the
large Northern colleges, the team
will suffer.

The Y. M. C. A. campaign which
began on Monday deserves to be
supported by all the members of
the University. Those who feel
that they cannot join the Association are urged at least to support the activities of the Y. M. C.

The activities which need your
support are:
1.—SociAL
a. Foreign Students.
About 20 in the Johns Hopkins
University are entertained at a
dinner, at which prominent American students meet them. Speakers such as President Goodnow
and Governor Harrington are
present as speakers. These students are also entertained once a
week in American homes. It
means much for a man from other
lands to be taken as a friend.
b. Receptions.
These are held throughout the
year, on, the type of the opening
reception.
c. Reading Room.
The reading room in the Barn is
maintained by the Y. M. C. A. In
it are all the current magazines,
newspapers, a Victrola and piano.
2.—EDUCATIONAL.
a. Open Forum.
Here the current problems of
the day are discussed. A prominent speaker talks for 20 minutes,
after which there is discussion
from the floor.
b. Life-Work Lectures.
One half the 1919 graduating
class had no idea as to what
should be their life-work. Such a
condition demands that all types
of life-work be intelligently presented. For these lectures, absolutely the best authorities have
been secured.
c. Social Science Club.
Here a more systematic study
of social problems is made, with
authorities as leaders of the discussion. This is an upper classmen's organization.
d. Social Service.
This involves teaching English
to Italians, Russians, etc. Often
these men are prepared for their
naturalization papers. This work
covers a wide area and demands
the help of 100 men.

The Debating Council has commenced its work early this year,
with a view to arranging the annual triangular debate in plenty
of time. The secretary has gotten
into communication with the Universities of North Carolina and
Virginia, and it is hoped that the
subject will soon be decided upon,
so that the junior-senior debate
may be held before Christmas.
Driver and Stein were appointed
a committee to meet with some
members of the Department of Political Economy to select a tentative subject. Although they have
not as yet announced their results,
it is apparent that some phase of
the labor question will furnish
abundant material.
At the first meeting, preliminary plans were settled, as far as
Johns Hopkins is concerned, for
the contest arranged by the newly
organized Southern Oratorical
League. This league, of which
Hopkins is a member, is composed of seven Southern colleges,
each being the leading, college in
its respective state. Under the
auspices of this league, there will
be held every year a contest in
oratory, in which each university
will be represented by one undergraduate speaker. Each contestant will be given twenty minutes
in which to discuss some live present-day economic or social problem, and will be judged on delivery, coherence of structure and
knowledge and treatment of the
subject. Extemporaneous speeches
are preferred.
The first contest will be held at
Lexington, Ky., as it was the University of Kentucky that planned
'and organized the league. It will
probably he held during the first
week in March.
It is the sincere wish of the
Debating Council that a large
number of candidates will report
when the preliminary tryouts are
announced in order that Hopkins
may be well represented both in
debating and in this first contest
of the Oratorical League.

Activities.

The real purpose of a college
career is to learn how to influence men. It has been said -that
the four years of college form the
period of life in which one gets
an opportunity to look out on the
world in a broad sort of way—to
survey life generally, looking over
the whole field before plunging into one's life-work, necessarily a
narrow channel of endeavor in
this age of specialization. A college accomplishes its purpose
through many ways—through its
studies, through its campus associations, through its activities.
There is another point of view
besides. this selfish one. An endowed institution like ours, developed by the untiring zeal of seleCted men and containing a spirit
nearly half a century old, offers
more than you can pay for. When
you have paid your fee at entrance
the account is not squared. You
still owe a little spirit, a little
work, a little participation in the
activities of Johns Hopkins.
There are at Hopkins two distinct sets of men: those who engage in these so-called college activities and those who do not. The
former class is much smaller numerically than the latter class.
Let us look closer at these
groups. There are more positions

of importance to be filled than
there are men in the first class.
Hence nearly every man in that
class holds not one position of.importance, but three or four. It is
obvious that these men are overburdened with Work and responsibility and are therefore unable to
(rive their undivided attention to
any one of them.
The larger class—those not engaged—meanwhile come selfishly
to college, take all they can in the
way of selfish benefits from Hopkins and then shirk quietly off
into the city with the booty they
have not really paid for. Little
care they for the college activities, little care they for associating with their fellows. They are
stealing from, instead of adding
to, college life. For them there is
no excuse, and they deserve nothing but contempt. Their selfish
lack of interest, their selfish nonparticipation is a powerful detriment to Hopkins.
The freshmen during their first
weeks of college have been deluged with opportunities to get
into the activities around them.
Here is the same danger. Some
may want to plunge into many of
them, dabble in them all and, lead
on by mere personal ambition,
spread out their talents over the
entire field. Others may be tempted. now to join the non-participants—the college slackers.
These men should stop now and
consider. A little self-examination and introspection, then each
and every man should enter some
one athletic, literary or other pursuit for which he is most fitted,
and then give it his undivided attention.

On Saturday, October 18, at
2:45 P. M., the freshman rooters
were again assembled On the
quadrangle in front of Gilman
Hall. Here they were formed according to sections, after which
the roll was called. Colonel Ellis
then gave a short talk, in which
he pointed out a few of the principal advantages to be derived
from joining the R. 0. T. C. This
talk was preparatory to the R.
0. T. C. campaign, which will take
place on Monday, October 20.
The sophomore sergeants then
made their reports, after which
members of the sophomore "pep"
committee inspected the ranks of
the freshies. Only one man had
failed to appear in the full freshman uniform, but an example was
made of him in front of the company.
The freshmen were then formed
into squads and marched over -to
Homewood Field, halting on the
way only to have their pictures
taken for this year's Hullabaloo.
At the field they were given seats
in the rooters' section, where they
acquitted themselves nobly.
Sergeant Cotton reports that
there were 120 freshmen absent,
but a few of these may have been
late and failed to report to him
at the field. These names he has
handed into the Student Conncilcil, but it is rumored unofficially that unless that body takes
more stringent action this week
than last, the sophomore "pep"
committee will take drastic action
to enforce the regulation requiring
all freshmen to be present at University games. . Indeed it is felt
by. some that many freshmen did
not report because they thought
that this regulation would remain
unenforced.

Prof. W. W. Willoughby is
again with us after an absence of
three years. During this period,
a large part of his time was spent
in the Far East, and he made
three trips to China and Japan.
Professor Willoughby was constitutional adviser to the Republic
of China during 1916, and in recent years he has had an excellent
opportunity of getting intimately
acquainted with the state of political affairs in these oriental countries. Professor Willoughby, as a
result of his wide experiences in
Japan and China, is now 'engaged
in the preparation of a volume
dealing with the rights of foreigners and of foreign nations in
China, and he hopes to publish
this book early in January.
His field has not been limited
to the East, however, for in 1918
his last published work, entitled
"Prussian Political Philosophy,"
appeared.
One of the latest and most
timely compositions of Professor
Willoughby is an article called
"Japan's Political Ethics," which
appeared in the September (1919)
number of Asia. This article is
of unusual import, because it discuses intelligently the manner in
which China has been treated by
Japan during recent years, with
special consideration of the muchdiscussed 'Shantung situation.
Both Professors Willoughby
and Lovejoy have been frequent
contributors to the new weekly
magazine, The Review, which was
recently started by two former
editors of The Nation, i. e., Fabian
Franklin, formerly a professor in
the Mathematical Department
here, and Mr. H. de W. Fuller.
Professor Lovejoy has recently
contributed an article discussing
whether there is a surplus of production in this country. It has
attracted much attention in this
country.

Activities.

The real purpose of a college
career is to learn how to influence men. It has been said -that
the four years of college form the
period of life in which one gets
an opportunity to look out on the
world in a broad sort of way—to
survey life generally, looking over
the whole field before plunging into one's life-work, necessarily a
narrow channel of endeavor in
this age of specialization. A college accomplishes its purpose
through many ways—through its
studies, through its campus associations, through its activities.
There is another point of view
besides. this selfish one. An endowed institution like ours, developed by the untiring zeal of seleCted men and containing a spirit
nearly half a century old, offers
more than you can pay for. When
you have paid your fee at entrance
the account is not squared. You
still owe a little spirit, a little
work, a little participation in the
activities of Johns Hopkins.
There are at Hopkins two distinct sets of men: those who engage in these so-called college activities and those who do not. The
former class is much smaller numerically than the latter class.
Let us look closer at these
groups. There are more positions

of importance to be filled than
there are men in the first class.
Hence nearly every man in that
class holds not one position of.importance, but three or four. It is
obvious that these men are overburdened with Work and responsibility and are therefore unable to
(rive their undivided attention to
any one of them.
The larger class—those not engaged—meanwhile come selfishly
to college, take all they can in the
way of selfish benefits from Hopkins and then shirk quietly off
into the city with the booty they
have not really paid for. Little
care they for the college activities, little care they for associating with their fellows. They are
stealing from, instead of adding
to, college life. For them there is
no excuse, and they deserve nothing but contempt. Their selfish
lack of interest, their selfish nonparticipation is a powerful detriment to Hopkins.
The freshmen during their first
weeks of college have been deluged with opportunities to get
into the activities around them.
Here is the same danger. Some
may want to plunge into many of
them, dabble in them all and, lead
on by mere personal ambition,
spread out their talents over the
entire field. Others may be tempted. now to join the non-participants—the college slackers.
These men should stop now and
consider. A little self-examination and introspection, then each
and every man should enter some
one athletic, literary or other pursuit for which he is most fitted,
and then give it his undivided attention.

Prof. W. W. Willoughby is
again with us after an absence of
three years. During this period,
a large part of his time was spent
in the Far East, and he made
three trips to China and Japan.
Professor Willoughby was constitutional adviser to the Republic
of China during 1916, and in recent years he has had an excellent
opportunity of getting intimately
acquainted with the state of political affairs in these oriental countries. Professor Willoughby, as a
result of his wide experiences in
Japan and China, is now 'engaged
in the preparation of a volume
dealing with the rights of foreigners and of foreign nations in
China, and he hopes to publish
this book early in January.
His field has not been limited
to the East, however, for in 1918
his last published work, entitled
"Prussian Political Philosophy,"
appeared.
One of the latest and most
timely compositions of Professor
Willoughby is an article called
"Japan's Political Ethics," which
appeared in the September (1919)
number of Asia. This article is
of unusual import, because it discuses intelligently the manner in
which China has been treated by
Japan during recent years, with
special consideration of the muchdiscussed 'Shantung situation.
Both Professors Willoughby
and Lovejoy have been frequent
contributors to the new weekly
magazine, The Review, which was
recently started by two former
editors of The Nation, i. e., Fabian
Franklin, formerly a professor in
the Mathematical Department
here, and Mr. H. de W. Fuller.
Professor Lovejoy has recently
contributed an article discussing
whether there is a surplus of production in this country. It has
attracted much attention in this
country.
